In this work, we synthesized a series of non-crystalline derivatives of Mn-BTC-BM MOF using a mechanochemical approach for NH3-selective catalytic reduction (SCR). The thermal decomposition of Mn-BTC-BM at 400gases yielded Mn (II, III) oxide (Mn-BTC-BM-400) with retained non-crystalline characteristics, which exhibited a smaller grain size and lower Mn-O bond energy than derivatives obtained through hydrothermal methods and other temperatures. This results in increased surface defects and acidic sites, promoting the release of lattice oxygen and leading to optimal low-temperature NH3-SCR activity. The Mn-BTC-BM-400 achieved an impressive 90 % conversion rate for NO at 170 ℃, and exhibited the lowest apparent activation energy (E a=18 kJ/mol) among the six catalysts. This study presents a simple synthesis approach for non-crystalline MnOx catalysts, with mechanochemical synthesis offering promising improvements in catalytic performance. Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) are a group of air pollutants that includes nitric oxide (NO) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2) [1]. NOx primarily originates from sources such as power plants, industrial exhaust gases, and vehicle emissions. One effective approach employing catalytic technology for reducing NOx is selective catalytic reduction with ammonia (NH3-SCR), which employs NH3 as a reducing agent in the presence of a catalyst [2,3]. Due to its high efficiency and rapid performance, NH3-SCR has become the dominant technology for industrial emissions control. However, traditional NH3-SCR catalysts face challenges in meeting the NOx conversion requirements of diesel engines, particularly in low-temperature conditions such as cold start and idle (150–180 ℃), as stipulated by China's National Emission Standard for Stage 6b (China VIb). In recent years, manganese (Mn) oxides (MnOx) have shown excellent catalytic performance in low-temperature NH3-SCR because of their diverse oxidation states, abundant surface reactive oxygen species, and unique redox properties [4,5]. MnOx are prepared using two methods: co-precipitation and precursor template pyrolysis [6–9]. Recent studies have highlighted the significant role of catalyst structure in catalytic performance [10,11]. Catalysts with porous and hierarchical structures offer advantages such as high surface area, efficient mass transfer, and short gas diffusion lengths, benefiting catalytic reactions [12]. However, conventional co-precipitation cannot precisely control the structure and morphology of a catalyst. Conversely, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted attention owing to their large surface area, high porosity, tunable pore sizes, well-defined structures, and adjustable chemical properties. Consequently, MOFs have been employed in various fields, including photocatalysis, adsorption, antibacterial activity, and medicine [13–17]. Notably, even after high-temperature pyrolysis, MOFs retain their original template pore structure and porosity, making them ideal precursors for the synthesizing metal, metal oxide, and carbon composite catalysts [8,9,18]. Jiang [19] synthesized MnOx nanoparticles via the thermal decomposition of Mn-MOF-74. These nanoparticles maintained the basal morphology of the Mn-MOF-74 nanospheres with increasing pyrolysis temperatures, resulting in porous surfaces. Pyrolyzing at 700 ℃ under a nitrogen (N2) atmosphere yielded MnOx with a mixed crystal phase of manganese (II, III) oxide (Mn3O4) and MnO, exhibiting the highest specific surface area (89.1 m2/g), NOx conversion rate (98 %), and nearly 100 % N2 selectivity. Zhang [20] investigated the impact of pyrolysis temperature on oxide formation using Mn-cerium (MnCe)-MOF precursors, characterizing the composite oxides at different temperatures. The study revealed that pyrolysis at 300 gases led to the composite oxides exhibiting higher molar ratios of Ce3+/Ce4+, Mn3+/Mn4+, and increased oxygen adsorption and surface oxygen vacancies. These factors contribute to the enhanced low-temperature oxidation of toluene. In summary, the thermal decomposition of MOF precursors offers advantages over precipitation methods for oxide preparation. However, MOFs and their derivatives synthesized by hydrothermal methods often possess well-defined crystalline properties, resulting in limited coordination of unsaturation points and active adsorption sites [21–23]. In contrast, amorphous metal-organic frameworks (aMOFs) with non-periodic atomic arrangements can generate a larger number of defects and unsaturated coordination sites on their surfaces, thereby providing abundant highly active sites. As a result, aMOFs exhibit superior catalytic performance than crystalline materials [24–27]. While most aMOFs are prepared by applying mechanical stress to the crystalline framework, excessive mechanical milling stress beyond the elastic limit of the MOFs can induce irreversible plastic deformation, leading to a high defect density and partial or complete loss of crystallinity [28]. Direct synthesis of aMOFs is rare, with only a few reported cases [29]. Therefore, future research should focus on the directly synthesizing aMOFs through one-step methods. Mechanochemical methods, specifically ball milling, promote chemical reactions through high-energy ball milling with or without minimal solvents. Synthesizing MOFs using mechanochemical methods offers advantages such as high product purity, short reaction time, and low energy consumption, making it a promising approach [30–32]. During the high-energy ball milling process, collisions between alumina balls can create more defect structures, such as dislocations, on the surface of the synthesized MOFs. MOFs with abundant defect structures can undergo thermal decomposition, generating defect-amorphous metal oxides or hydroxides in situ at the metal active sites. This enhancement contributes to improved catalytic performance [26,32]. Currently, there is limited research on the application of amorphous materials in NH3-SCR, making this experiment crucial for NH3-SCR studies. In this study, we synthesized an amorphous Mn-BTC precursor using a mechanochemical method, and obtained a series of crystalline and amorphous MnOx catalysts by controlling the pyrolysis temperature. The main objective of this study is to compare the catalytic performances of crystalline and amorphous MnOx in NH3-SCR. Experimental The details of the experimental procedure are provided in S (Supporting Information), and the synthetic process is illustrated in Fig. 1 . Results and discussion Structure and morphology of catalyst The thermal decomposition of the Tg comprises three stages as shown in Fig. 2 . The first stage, below 200 °C, involves the loss of various solvents within the pores of the MOFs. The second stage, from 200 to 300 °C, corresponds to the loss of weakly coordinated molecules, such as dimethylformamide (DMF), as indicated by the X-ray diffraction (XRD) crystal structure. The third stage, from 300 to 400 °C, corresponds to the decomposition of the ligand BTC. Additionally, beyond 350 °C, the decomposition of the ligand became less pronounced, possibly owing to phase transitions. Based on the spectrum presented in Fig. 3 b, the XRD peaks of Mn-BTC-BM and Mn-BTC-HT obtained using mechanochemical and hydrothermal methods, respectively, exhibited good compatibility with the desired Mn-BTC compound [33]. This confirmed the successful synthesis of the Mn6-(HCOO)6(BTC)2(DMF)6 precursor using both mechanochemical and hydrothermal approaches. In comparison, the precursor synthesized through the mechanochemical method displays broader peaks, indicating lower crystallinity and smaller grain size due to the ball milling process, leading to an amorphous-like material. Fig. 3a suggests the possibility of a phase transition as the calcination temperature is increased from 350 to 550gases. The grain sizes of the samples were determined using the Scherrer equation, and the results are presented in Table 1 . In the XRD spectrum of Mn-BTC-350 (Fig. 3a), characteristic diffraction peaks are evident at 2θ = 18°, 29°, 32°, 36°, 38°, 44°, 51°, 58°, 59°, and 64°, which correspond to the typical peaks of Mn3O4 (JCPDS PDF#24-0734) [34]. However, at higher temperatures, the intensities of the characteristic Mn3O4 peaks and the grain size decreased. This suggests the presence of an amorphous MnOx phase during the transformation from Mn3O4 to manganese(III) oxide (Mn2O3), which potentially contributes to the catalytic activity in NH3-SCR at lower temperatures [35–37]. With further heating to 450gases, the majority of the Mn3O4 crystals transform into Mn2O3, as evidenced by the characteristic peaks at 2θ = 22°, 33°, 38°, 45°, 49°, 55°, and 66°, corresponding to Mn2O3 (JCPDS PDF#41-1442) [38]. However, weak characteristic peaks of the Mn3O4 phase still persist at 2θ = 36° and 59°. As the calcination temperature increases to 500 and 550gases, the characteristic peaks of Mn3O4 gradually vanish, and the peaks of Mn2O3 at 500 and 550gases become more pronounced than those at 450gases. According to the Scherrer formula, the grain size increases from 19.7 to 29.1 nm between 400 and 550gases, as shown in Table 1. The Mn2O3 crystals obtained by the thermal decomposition of Mn-BTC-HT at 400gases exhibit relatively high purity and enhanced crystallinity. Notably, in contrast to polycrystalline Mn3O4, Mn2O3 crystals possess larger sizes, potentially resulting in fewer exposed active sites. Table 1 summarizes the main crystal phases of the samples obtained at various calcination temperatures. As the calcination temperature increases from 350 to 550gases, the crystal phases of MnOx undergo a transformation from Mn3O4 (350–400gases) to Mn2O3 (450–550gases). Furthermore, there was a decrease in the specific surface area and total pore volume, accompanied by an increase in the average pore size as the calcination temperature increased. This phenomenon can be attributed to the transition of the material from an amorphous to a crystalline state, leading to an increase in the grain size and the partial collapse of the Mn2O3 framework. Consequently, the average pore size increased, and the specific surface area decreased, which is consistent with the increasing intensity of the characteristic Mn2O3 peaks observed in Fig. 3a as the pyrolysis temperature increased. The grain size decrease observed between 350 and 400gases can be associated with the imminent phase transition of Mn3O4. Comparing the specific surface area, pore volume, and grain size of the MnOx samples obtained by calcination at 400gases using hydrothermal and mechanochemical methods, it is evident that the Mn3O4 obtained through ball milling exhibits a higher specific surface area of 50.9 m2/g, whereas the Mn2O3 obtained via the hydrothermal method shows a specific surface area of 23.3 m2/g. Moreover, the grain size and pore volume of the MnOx obtained by ball milling were superior to those obtained using the hydrothermal method. Raman spectroscopy is a technique commonly employed to characterize crystal structures. As depicted in Fig. 5, MnOx displays two peaks at approximately 315 and 650 cm–1. The most prominent peak corresponds to the stretching vibration of the Mn-O bonds within the [MnO6] octahedra, whereas the peak at 315 cm–1 corresponds to the bending vibration of the Mn-O bonds [39,40]. With an increase in the calcination temperature, the strongest peak underwent a red shift, followed by a blue shift, and the peak width gradually decreased. This observation suggests that the strength of the Mn-O bonds initially decreases and then increases [41], indicating an enhancement in the crystallinity of the resulting MnOx. Furthermore, the Mn-O bond energy is minimized in the Mn3O4 obtained through the thermal decomposition of Mn-BTC-BM at 400gases. The Raman spectrum of the Mn3O4 obtained at 400gases exhibits significant broadening, indicative of smaller grain sizes and supporting the presence of amorphous and polycrystalline MnOx species. In accordance with the XRD spectrum, the characteristic peaks of Mn3O4 diminish in intensity in the MnOx sample obtained at 400gases. This phenomenon can be attributed to the formation of an amorphous phase during the transition from Mn3O4 to Mn2O3, which introduces more vacancies and defects. The presence of defects and vacancies weakens the strength of the Mn-O bonds [42,43]. Consequently, after the formation of Mn3O4 through the thermal decomposition of Mn-BTC-BM at 400℃, some lattice oxygen is released, resulting in the creation of oxygen vacancies. This observation aligns with the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results and plays a pivotal role in enhancing catalytic activity. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were used to observe the morphological characteristics of the oxides synthesized from the precursor at various pyrolysis temperatures. Figs. 6a and b illustrate that the surface of Mn3O4 obtained at 350gases exhibits fibrous morphology, with slight aggregation is observed at 400gases. These findings were consistent with the BET results. At 450gases, Mn2O3 exhibits a denser pore structure (Fig. 4 b). As the temperature increases to 500 and 550gases, Mn2O3 demonstrates particle aggregation, particularly evident at 550gases (Fig. 6 d and e). The Mn2O3 synthesized using the hydrothermal method exhibited a thicker lamellar structure (Fig. 6f). EDS results showed that the highest oxygen atom ratio of Mn-BTC-BM-400 was 50.67 % (as Figs. 7 b and Table 2 ), and the oxygen atom ratio gradually decreased with the increase of pyrolysis temperature. Mn-BTC-BM-400 also has the strongest oxidation due to its high oxygen atom proportion. NH3 adsorbed on the catalyst surface is also dehydrogenated due to its high oxidation activity and a rapid SCR reaction occurs. This is also one of the reasons why Mn-BTC-BM-400 has the best catalytic activity. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images illustrate that the grain size of MnOx gradually increased with increasing temperature elevation (Figs. 8 b, f, j, n, and r). Additionally, as the crystal phase of MnOx changed, the exposed crystal facets also changed. At 350gases, Mn3O4 primarily exposes the (211) crystal facet (Fig. 8c and d). At 400gases, some Mn3O4 undergoes a crystal phase transition, primarily exposing the (211) crystal facet of Mn3O4 and a small amount of (211) crystal facet of Mn2O3 (Fig. 8g and h). At 450gases, the crystal phase transition of Mn2O3 completes, mainly exposing the (222) and (622) crystal facets (Figs. 8k and l). Furthermore, MnOx obtained at 350, 400, and 450gases exhibit overlapping and intersecting crystalline, amorphous, and polycrystalline surfaces, which can introduce more defects and vacancies into MnOx. As the calcination temperature increases, Mn2O3 mainly exposes the (222) facet (Fig. 8o, p, s, and t). The selected area diffraction (SAED) patterns of each oxide simultaneously exhibited diffraction spots and rings, indicating that Mn-BTC-BM-350, Mn-BTC-BM-400, and Mn-BTC-BM-450 are amorphous and polycrystalline composites [19]. As the pyrolysis temperature increases, the diffraction rings gradually darken and disappear while the diffraction spots become brighter, indicating that Mn2O3 transforms into a single crystal material at 500 and 550gases. Heterostructures formed at the interfaces of polycrystalline materials can create interfacial defects and oxygen vacancies, which are beneficial for catalytic reactions. XPS XPS was used to quantitatively analyze the surface chemical states of the catalysts. Fig. 9 depicts the O1s and Mn 2p spectra. The O1s binding energies are presented in Fig. 9(a), where the range of 531.7 to 531.9 eV and 530.0 to 530.2 eV corresponds to the surface-adsorbed oxygen (Osur) and lattice oxygen (Olatt), respectively [44]. The Mn 2p binding energies are shown in Fig. 9(b), with the range of 653.1 to 653.8 eV and 641.3 eV to 641.9 eV representing Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2, respectively. The binding energies of Mn4+ is 643.4 eV, while Mn3+ exhibits binding energies of 641.7 eV [44–47]. As the calcination temperature increases, the ratio of Mn3+/Mn4 + gradually decreases, whereas the proportion of Mn3+ initially increases and then decreases. According to previous study, the oxygen vacancy in Mn3O4 is more likely to adsorb free oxygen into surface oxygen [48]. This is also an important factor affecting the highest oxygen adsorption content on the surface of Mn-BTC-BM-400. In this study, as the ratio of Mn3+/Mn4 + decreased, the surface oxygen content also decreased. Notably, MnOx obtained at 400gases exhibits the highest surface oxygen content, which is advantageous for the low-temperature oxidation of NO. This finding aligns with the experimental results reported by Zhang and Yang [44,49]. NH3-TPD and O2-TPD Regarding SCR, the adsorption and activation of NH3 on the catalyst surface are crucial for the overall catalytic process. Therefore, the acidity of the SCR catalyst surface plays a significant role in determining its catalytic activity. NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was utilized to characterize the acid strength and surface acid quantity of the catalyst, as shown in Fig. 10 a. BM-350 exhibited characteristic peaks around 270, 500, and 550gases, while BM-400 showed no significant peaks below 400gases and displayed two characteristic peaks around 450 and 570gases. HT-400 demonstrated no significant peaks below 400gases and exhibited one characteristic peak around 570gases. BM-450 displayed a characteristic peak around 540gases. BM-500 and BM-550 showed no significant peaks below 600℃. The temperature ranges of 100–200, 200–400, and 400–600gases corresponded to regions of weak, medium-strong, and strong acids, respectively. However, none of the six catalysts exhibited notable characteristic peaks within the 100–400gases range, indicating that the adsorption sites of the MnOx synthesized in this experiment were primarily concentrated on Lewis acid sites [50,51]. As illustrated in Fig. 10, the Mn3O4 derived from calcination at 400gases exhibited the highest surface acid content, which progressively decreased with increasing calcination temperature. The increase in the crystallinity of polycrystalline MnOx led to a decrease in the specific surface area and reduced the exposure of surface acid sites. To investigate the migration of surface oxygen species on the catalyst, O2-temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD) tests were conducted, as illustrated in Fig. 10b. Three types of oxygen species were identified based on the sample curves. The temperature ranges of 50–120, 120–450, and 450–600gases corresponded to surface molecular oxygen (O2), chemisorbed oxygen (α-O), and surface lattice oxygen (α'-O), respectively [45,52]. Within the 50–450gases range, the peak area of BM-400 was slightly larger than that of BM-350 and significantly larger than that of the other samples, indicating that BM-400 possessed the highest amount of surface chemisorbed oxygen. Within the 450–600gases range, BM-400 exhibited the highest content of lattice oxygen. This can be attributed to the lower Mn-O bond strength in BM-400, which makes it easier for the Mn-O bonds to break at high temperatures and release more lattice oxygen. Rapid conversion between lattice oxygen and surface-adsorbed oxygen can enhance the oxygen release capability of the catalyst, which is crucial for catalytic activity. Both BM-400 and HT-400 were obtained as MnOx precursors at 400gases, but BM-400 demonstrated significantly stronger oxidation ability than HT-400. This indicates that the amorphous Mn3O4 derived from the mechanochemical method outperforms the crystalline Mn2O3 phase in terms of catalytic performance. As the pyrolysis temperature increases, the peak areas in each temperature range gradually decrease. In the samples obtained through calcination at 500 and 550℃, only surface molecular oxygen and a small amount of chemisorbed oxygen were detected. This can be attributed to the high crystallinity of the Mn2O3 obtained at these two temperatures, which results in more stable Mn-O bonds that are less prone to breaking and releasing lattice oxygen. Hydrogen H2-TPR The H2-TPR profiles in Fig. 11 depict the MnOx series. Mn-BTC-BM-550 exhibits a slightly lower oxidation capacity, possibly due to increased crystallinity and stronger Mn-O bonds, leading to reduced lattice oxygen reactivity. Mn-BTC-BM-350, Mn-BTC-BM-400, and Mn-BTC-HT400 exhibited three reduction peaks in the H2-TPR curves, corresponding to the reduction of MnO2 to Mn2O3, Mn2O3 to Mn3O4, and Mn3O4 to MnO, respectively [53,54]. Mn-BTC-BM-400, with the lowest temperature peak, played a crucial role in achieving optimal low-temperature catalytic activity. The reduction peak temperatures for Mn-BTC-BM-450 and Mn-BTC-BM-500 followed the sequences MnO2 to Mn2O3 and Mn2O3 to MnO, respectively [55]. For Mn-BTC-BM-550, the reduction peak temperatures increased from Mn2O3 to Mn3O4 and from Mn3O4 to MnO [53]. Catalytic performance This study investigated the catalytic performances of MnOx catalysts prepared by mechanochemical and hydrothermal methods. Fig. 12 presents the NOx conversion rates obtained. Mn-BTC-BM-400 achieved an impressive 90 % conversion rate for NO at 170gases, demonstrating its superior performance at low temperatures. Mn-BTC-BM-350 displayed comparable catalytic activity to Mn-BTC-BM-400 at temperatures below 150gases. However, as the temperature increased, the NO conversion rate of Mn-BTC-BM-350 lagged that of Mn-BTC-BM-400. This difference can be attributed to the lower Mn-O bond strength in Mn-BTC-BM-400, which facilitated the release of lattice oxygen. Compared to Mn-BTC-BM-350, the low-temperature properties of Mn-BTC-BM-500 and Mn-BTC-BM-550 were reduced; however, they had a wider active temperature window owing to their higher crystallinity and more stable crystal structure. In contrast, Mn-BTC-HT-400 (prepared using the hydrothermal method) possessed a higher surface oxygen content but a significantly lower specific surface area than Mn-BTC-BM-350. Hence, although its low-temperature catalytic rate was comparable to that of Mn-BTC-BM-350, its operating temperature range was narrower. As the crystallinity of the MnOx series increased, the corresponding catalytic activities followed the order Mn-BTC-BM-400>Mn-BTC-BM-350>Mn-BTC-HT-400>Mn-BTC-BM-450>Mn-BTC-BM-500>Mn-BTC-BM-550. This observation highlights the superiority of amorphous materials for low-temperature NH3-SCR catalysis. As the temperature increases, the N2 selectivity of all MnOx catalysts decreases. Mn-BTC-BM-400 shows the lowest N2 selectivity at the same temperature, possibly because of its strong oxidation properties, causing an oxidative side reaction of NH3, resulting in decreased N2 selectivity. Fig. 13 illustrates the temperature dependence of the NH3-SCR reaction rate constant for different MnOx catalysts, which indicates that Mn-BTC-BM-400 exhibits the lowest apparent activation energy (E a=18 kJ/mol), implying that NH3-SCR occurs more readily on this catalyst. Additionally, as the pyrolysis temperature increases, the apparent activation energy gradually increases, suggesting that NH3-SCR becomes more challenging to facilitate. Table 3 lists the catalytic activities of typical Mn based catalysts for NH3-SCR reported in literatures. It can be seen that the catalytic activity of Mn-BTC-BM-400 for NH3-SCR reaction is comparable to that of composite metal oxides. In situ diffuse-reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFT) To elucidate the mechanism of low-temperature SCR of MnOx, DRIFT tests were conducted on Mn-BTC-BM-400. Fig. 14 a shows bands at 3250 cm–1 corresponding to NH3 NH stretching [58] and bands at 1705, 1622, and 1252 cm–1 associated with NH3 coordination to Lewis acids [59,60]. The bands at 1687, 1455, and 1400 cm–1 indicate symmetric bending vibrations of NH4+ on Brønsted acid sites [61–63]. The bands at 1520 and 1366 cm–1 were attributed to -NH2 and oxidized NH3 [62,64]. These results indicated that NH3 was dehydrogenated on the catalyst surface. The excellent dehydrogenation ability of MnOx contributed to its low-temperature catalytic activity. None of the characteristic peaks changed one hour after N2 purging, indicating that NH3 adsorption on the catalyst surface occurred via chemisorption. In Fig. 14b, reactions between NO+O2 and the pre-adsorbed NH3 are observed. The new bands at 1770 and 1618 cm–1 were assigned to nitrogen tetroxide (N2O4) and gaseous NO2 [65,56]. N2O4 reacts with H2O to form nitrous acid (HONO) and nitric acid (HONO2), which further react with NH3 to produce ammonium nitrite (NH4NO2) and ammonium nitrate (NH4NO3). NH4NO3 reacted with NO to produce NH4 NO2 and NO2, whereas NH4NO2 decomposes into N2 and H2O [57]. The new bands at 1350,1040, and 820 cm–1 were identified as free NO3–, bidentate nitrate, nitrite, or nitrate species [60,56]. The peaks associated with gaseous or weakly adsorbed NH3, NH4+, and -NH2 gradually weakened and disappeared at 200 °C. Furthermore, with most NH3 species having completed their reactions, the formation of N2O4, NO2, and various nitrates suggested the occurrence of a “Fast SCR” process involving NO and the remaining NH3 species. Fig. 15 a shows the infrared spectrum of NO+O2 adsorption on the surface of Mn-BTC-BM-400. The peaks at 1780–1770 cm−1 and 1627–1610 cm−1 belong to N2O4 and adsorbed NO2, respectively [60,56]. The peaks at 1350 and 820 cm−1 are attributed to NO3 − and nitrite species [65,56]. It can be clearly observed that after NO+O2 adsorption is completed and nitrogen purge for 60 min, the characteristic peak of NO2 adsorption at 1627–1610 cm−1 disappears, indicating that NO2 belongs to physical adsorption on the catalyst surface. After NO+O2 pretreatment, Mn-BTC-BM-400 passed into NH3, and there was no significant change in the intensity of each characteristic peak, indicating that N2O4, NO3- and nitrite species were not reactive in NH3-SCR reaction [57,66]. It also shows that the reaction of NH3-SCR on the surface of Mn-BTC-BM-400 catalyst does not follow the L-H mechanism. There was no obvious NH3 characteristic peak during the heating reaction, which may be because the nitrate and nitrite species on the surface occupied the active site on the catalyst surface. These characteristics indicate that NH3 initially adsorbs onto the Lewis and Brønsted acid sites and subsequently reacts with NO in the gas phase following the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism, as Fig. 16 . Conclusions A series of MnOx samples were obtained by controlling the pyrolysis temperature and synthesis method, and their NH3-SCR activities were compared. Among them, Mn-BTC-BM-400 demonstrated the highest oxidation performance, which could be attributed to the presence of crystalline, amorphous, and polycrystalline phases. Mn-BTC-BM-400 exhibited the best low-temperature catalytic activity. The precursor of Mn-BTC, synthesized using the mechanochemical method, exhibited the characteristics of a MOF materials, whereas the precursor obtained through the hydrothermal method showed the characteristics of crystalline MOF materials. Consequently, for the same pyrolysis temperature, the resulting Mn-BTC-BM-400 exhibited an amorphous structure. It possesses a larger specific surface area than Mn-BTC-HT-400, with a smaller grain size and a greater number of exposed active sites. The interface between the crystalline, amorphous, and polycrystalline states contains surface defects and vacancies, resulting in a high surface oxygen content. This, along with the synergistic effect of oxygen vacancies and a high proportion of Mn3+, contributed to the catalytic activity of the catalyst at low temperatures. Amorphous materials generally exhibit better catalytic performance owing to their surface defects and high specific surface areas. However, their stabilities require further investigation. coredata.dc:description: Amorphous metal oxides have aroused extensive research interest in heterogeneous catalysis owing to their high surface area and rich surface defects. In this work, we synthesized a series of non-crystalline derivatives of Mn-BTC-BM MOF using a mechanochemical approach for NH3-selective catalytic reduction (SCR). The thermal decomposition of Mn-BTC-BM at 400gases yielded Mn (II, III) oxide (Mn-BTC-BM-400) with retained non-crystalline characteristics, which exhibited a smaller grain size and lower Mn-O bond energy than derivatives obtained through hydrothermal methods and other temperatures. This results in increased surface defects and acidic sites, promoting the release of lattice oxygen and leading to optimal low-temperature NH3-SCR activity. The Mn-BTC-BM-400 achieved an impressive 90 % conversion rate for NO at 170 ℃, and exhibited the lowest apparent activation energy (E a=18 kJ/mol) among the six catalysts. This study presents a simple synthesis approach for non-crystalline MnOx catalysts, with mechanochemical synthesis offering promising improvements in catalytic performance.
coredata.dc:title: Mn MOF-derivatives synthesized based upon a mechanochemistry method for low-temperature NH3- SCR: From amorphous precursor to amorphous catalyst
